thread.title: BizBeat: Businesses helping local child, Denim & Diamonds tickets on sale
thread.title_full: BizBeat: Businesses helping local child, Denim & Diamonds tickets on sale

author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
title: BizBeat: Businesses helping local child, Denim & Diamonds tickets on sale
text:
Happening this week in and around Cecil County:
September is Childhood Cancer Awareness Month and area businesses are joining forces to help in the fight; with one particular family in mind.
The Wheelie Bar, a food truck specializing in lemonades, teas, dirty sodas, energy drinks and more, will donate $1 from every Georgia Peach-flavored drink to help the Callis family and little Georgia in her fight against cancer.
Rise N Grind Cafe, a coffee house with sandwiches and baked goods and Garden Girl, a salad and sandwich bar, will donate the proceeds of sales of their weekend specials Sept. 5-7 also to benefit Georgia and her family.
Georgia Callis was diagnosed two years ago with leukemia. Garden Girl and Rise N Grind are located at 2 and 8 East Main St. in Rising Sun. The Wheelie Bar can be found at Bay Ace Hardware in Rising Sun Monday nights from 4 until 9 p.m., at the North East Farmer’s Market the second and fourth Saturdays from 8 a.m. until noon at 135 South Main St. Check The Wheelie Bar Facebook page for other event locations.
•••
Elkton Ace Home & Farm, 728 East Pulaski Highway, has a Sundae Social Weekend Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m.
There will be free ice cream served plus the Slime Sundae Bar will offer a $5 special.
•••
Polka Dot Powerhouse held their first Cecil County meeting last week at Lee’s Landing Dock Bar, and nearly two dozen ladies attended.
Dawn Regner, Managing Director of the Northern Chesapeake Chapter of the international women’s organization, said the Cecil County chapter is needed because the bylaws keep the meetings small. The Harford County meetings had a wait list, and half of the women at each meeting in Belcamp, Md., were from Cecil County.
At the inaugural meeting in Port Deposit, Regner said that — moving forward — the Cecil County Chapter of Polka Dot Powerhouse will meet the third Thursday of each month at Granite Run Taproom. Mark your calendar for Sept. 18 from 3:30 until 5.
To register for the meeting, go to: https://tinyurl.com/3r8yfua7
Granite Run Taproom is located at 26 South Main St. in Port Deposit.
•••
AquaBoost Pressure Washing, based in Rising Sun, has partnered with a like-minded Harford County company to start folks thinking about the upcoming holidays.
Working with UR Washed Power Washing LLC, the companies are offering to do the exterior decorating of your home or business with all that’s merry and bright.
Call 443-252-1631 to make an appointment to get on their schedule.
•••
An Elkton printing company is expanding its reach beyond Cecil County.
Located at 873 Pulaski Highway, Pacesetter Signs now reaches Philadelphia, Pa. with its custom sign design and application services. Pacesetter signs offers consultation, manufacturing, installations, repairs and maintenance as well. Call 443-227-4106 to contact Michael Pace at Pacesetter Signs.
•••
Tickets are on sale now at Elkton Music Hall for the Dec. 20 concert by Green River, a Creedence Clearwater Revival Tribute band. For tickets, go to: https://tinyurl.com/ywprkhb9
Meanwhile, the 3rd Annual Jimmy Buffet Party is Aug. 30 starting at 6 p.m. at the hall, 107 North St. in Elkton. This is a free show promising cocktails, music and good times. Smoke N Meats BBQ will bring the food truck. Play games and get ready for a sing along. Reserve your seat at: https://tinyurl.com/cytk6e3u
•••
CHEP Outpost, a thrift store that supports veterans in Cecil County, is in search of vendors, crafters, food trucks and more for its Sept. 13 Second Saturday event. There is a final Second Saturday Oct. 11. Both events run from 9 a.m. until 2 p.m.
Located at 124 Greenmount Road, off of US Route 1 between Rising Sun and Nottingham, Pa., CHEP Outpost has a tiered price list for participants for these outdoor, highly visible events. To sign up, go to: https://tinyurl.com/bdhpxfzd
•••
A Cecil College Nursing student is the recipient of a $2,500 scholarship from the Dunkin’ Baltimore/Metro DC Regional Scholarship Program.
Stephanie Hutchinson Maahs was one of 50 students, regionally, to be recognized and rewarded for academic excellence, leadership, and community involvement.
Maahs, from Middletown, Del., called the presentation ceremony “amazing.”
“Everything was so nice. It felt really good to be recognized for our hard work,” she said.
•••
The Denim & Diamonds Gala hosted by BW Unlimited Charity Fundraising is set for Sept. 27 at Martin’s West in Baltimore to benefit After The Races.
Tickets are $125 per person. Business and individual sponsorships, as well as donations for raffles to be held that night can be arranged by contacting Grace at 585-748-8113. An email can be sent instead to gracef802@gmail.com.
After The Races operates as a non-profit organization on Appleton Road north of Elkton, taking in retired racehorses and rehabilitating them for private ownership and enjoyment. As the name implies, to attend the Denim & Diamonds Gala, one can go formal or go casual, or perhaps a little bit of both.
Martin’s West is located at 6817 Dogwood Road in Baltimore, Md.
•••
Amber Askew, Chief Financial Officer for APGFCU, has been recognized as a 40 Under 40 honoree by the Baltimore Business Journal.
Askew was listed with other young professionals who are making contributions in their communities as well as their industries.
“Amber’s leadership and vision have been instrumental to our growth and continued service to our members,” said Becky Smith, President/CEO. “We are proud of Amber and her continued commitment to our mission and the communities we serve.”
Business Beat is a weekly column on business happenings in and around Cecil County. If you are interested in having your business featured in this free column, contact Jane Bellmyer at jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com or 443-245-5007.
